awd_titl_txt: UNS: Airborne Microbes as Mitigators of Greenhouse Gases
awd_abstract_narration:
1512511 (Fennell)

Microorganisms in air are typically assumed to be inactive. Yet air contains microbial growth substrates, and microbes known to metabolize these substrates have been collected from the atmosphere. It is not known whether microbes in ambient air are capable of inducing biogeochemical change on a global scale, as they are in other Earth environments. In this research metabolic activity of bacteria exposed to gaseous growth substrates in natural air will be investigated. The mitigation of two of the major greenhouse gases (GHG), methane and carbon dioxide, by airborne bacteria will be investigated, as well as potential interventions to enhance the effect. 

Microbial metabolism in air could be an important and modifiable sink for atmospheric contaminants including methane and carbon dioxide. Positive findings from this project could stimulate cross-disciplinary collaboration with atmospheric chemists and modelers to incorporate activity of natural airborne microbes into conceptual models and eventually quantitative models of atmospheric processes. Knowledge of microbial activity, metabolism and/or growth in the atmosphere would establish the atmosphere as part of the biosphere. This research expands upon a previous NSF project where the PIs developed rotating gas-phase bioreactors for aerial incubation of bacteria (Fennell, PI, Mainelis, co-PI; MCB-0606576) and where they have shown that airborne bacteria are active (Fennell, PI, Mainelis and Kerkhof coPIs; IOS-1022254). The hypotheses governing the continuing study are that active microorganisms in the atmosphere play a role in mitigation of greenhouse gases including methane and carbon dioxide and that this role could be enhanced by ecological engineering intervention. Specifically, this research will characterize methane and carbon dioxide biotransformation and uptake by airborne methanotrophic and phototrophic bacteria, respectively, under environmental conditions of light/dark and differing humidities and temperatures, addressing the question, what are the environmental factors that constrain activity of airborne GHG mitigating microbes?

This award is co-funded by the MCB Division of the BIO Directorate and the CBET/ENG Environmental Sustainability program under BIOMAPS.

por.por_cntn:
Microorganisms enter the atmosphere from the Earth′s surface through a variety of mechanisms. These microorganisms may remain in the atmosphere for minutes, hours, days, or even weeks.  Microbes in the atmosphere may be found in droplets of rain water, fog or cloud water, or they may be suspended in the air. Very little is known about what microbes in the atmosphere are capable of doing. This project investigated whether microbes that are suspended in air are active and carry out metabolism as they do in other environments on the Earth′s surface such as soil or water. In particular we investigated whether microbes in air metabolize two greenhouse gases found in the atmosphere: methane and carbon dioxide.  Methanotrophic microorganisms convert methane into carbon dioxide.  Phototrophic microbes metabolize carbon dioxide and fix it into new cellular material. Their activity could help remove greenhouse gases from the atmosphere.

 

Our project used DNA stable isotope probing to determine if airborne microbial cells metabolize methane or carbon dioxide. Microbes suspended in air were fed methane or carbon dioxide made with a rare isotope of carbon, carbon 13, instead of carbon 12, which is naturally abundant.  If the microbes take up and metabolize the labelled methane or carbon dioxide and divide, new DNA formed will be made of carbon 13. This heavy DNA can be separated from the original DNA and its detection shows that the airborne microbes are active.

 

Methanotrophic microbial enrichment cultures were started by inoculation with particles recovered from air and from microbes rinsed off maple leaves. A phototrophic cyanobacterium, Synechococcus, was purchased and grown in culture and phototrophic enrichments were established using cloudwater collected from Puy de Dome, France, as inoculum. Additionally, we used Sphingomonas aerolata, a bacterium that lives on organic compounds (but not methane or carbon dioxide) as a control.  The liquid cultures were grown to produce abundant cells. Cells were captured from liquid culture and aerosolized using a single pass aerosol generator into  320 L rotating reactors where they were held in the airborne state for days. 

 

The first important outcome of our study is that our results indicate that under some conditions, airborne phototrophs and methanotrophs do metabolize their substrates, because we detected heavy DNA. However, our results show that this activity does not always occur or that it is not always possible to detect it. This may be because the microbes did not grow (divide) during our experiments, or that the amount of airborne cells, and thus the amount of DNA recovered, was too low to allow us to detect the heavy DNA. Future work should focus on using even more sensitive techniques to detect activity in airborne cells.

 

A second outcome of our work involved characterizing phototrophic microbes from the atmosphere. We collaborated with scientists at Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique, Universite Clermont Auvergne, France, to obtain cloudwater from the Observatoire de Physique du Globe de Clermont-Ferrand at Puy de Dome, an ancient volcano that rises 1465 m above sea level. The cloud water was enriched under conditions to promote the growth of photosynthethic microorganisms. Surprisingly, the major organism detected in these enrichments was not a bacterium, but rather a green algae of the family Chlorellaceae. The predominant organism in all three cloud enrichments we developed matched with Chloroidium saccharophila SAG 211-9a, a terrestrial single celled algae that is normally associated with plant surfaces, and is known to be able to survive harsh environmental conditions such as dessication. We performed experiments to aerosolize these rather large organisms and hold them in the air. They can be recaptured from the reactors and they retain the ability to grow.  Future work will focus on understanding how this microbe adapts to survival in the atmosphere, and to understanding if it remains active in the atmosphere.

 

The third outcome of our work is the training of one PhD student in methods for studying microorganisms in the atmosphere, and five undergraduate students in laboratory techniques such as culturing microorganisms and operation of gas chromatographs.  Outreach to the public via hands-on demostrations of environmental quality related to air and water by group members at Rutgers Day, an annual open house at Rutger University that serves approximately 100,000 visitors yearly.

 

Microbial metabolism in air could be an important and modifiable sink for atmospheric contaminants including methane and carbon dioxide. Our project has developed data indicating that methanotrophic and phototrophic bacteria may incorporate methane and carbon dioxide into new cellular biomass in the airborne state, but that DNA stable isotope probing may not be sensitive enough to routinely detect this activity. We have shown with our French collaborators that phototrophic organisms are present in clouds and rain.  Algae enriched from cloudwater can be held and survive in the airborne state.
